newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil to revise 1997/98 alcohol quotas by August.
newsitem.headline: Brazil to revise 1997/98 alcohol quotas by August.

text.p: Brazil is set to revise alcohol production quotas set out in its 1997/98 sugar crop plan by the end of August, according to a decree published in the government's official bulletin.

Producers will have to hire an independent inspector to certify all origin, production and stock information presented by producers and cooperatives to the Industry and Commerce Ministry (MICT), the decree said.

The measure is aimed at eliminating "phantom" alcohol production in the north-east of Brazil, where many companies are allocated an alcohol production quota when in fact they only produce sugar, a producer representative said.

"This decree is a result of a request by producers in the north-east to regulate the amounts of alcohol said to be there. There is a lot of 'paper' alcohol there," said Claudio Manesco of the Sao Paulo Sugar Industry Union (Unica).
"I don't see any impact for the center-south," he added.

The new quotas will be used to calculate the subsidies to which companies are entitled in compensation for alcohol production costs and for the differential between alcohol and gasoline prices, the MICT said.
The 1997/98 crop plan, published in May, sees total alcohol production at 16.73 million cubic meters, up sharply from the 13.89 million cubic meters allocated for alcohol production in 1996/97.
